name: smelting and refining of nickel concentrate, 7% Ni | steam, in chemical industry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22404/documentation

This dataset is based on the following publication:  Deng, S. Y., & Gong, X. Z. (2018). Life Cycle Assessment of Nickel Production in China. Materials Science Forum, 913, 1004-1010. doi:10.4028/www.scientific.net/MSF.913.1004 . Specific modifications were made in order to make the dataset more transparent.The publication deals with the pyrometallurgical production of electrolytic nickel (99.98% concentrated) by sulfide ore (1% concentration). This activity represents the production of nickel class I  (99.98% purity)  from nickel concentrate (6.78% concentration).   

The activity starts with the smelting of the nickel concentrate, 6.78% beneficiated, which is the outcome of mining and beneficiation processes of nickel sulfidic ore.

The activity ends with the production of refined nickel, 99.98% concentrated.

No allocation is applied.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset valid for the entire corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The nickel concentrate (6.78% beneficiated - product of the mining and beneficiation processes) undergoes drying, melting in flash furnace and converting to produce high nickel matte. The nickel matte undergoes grinding-floating separation and is refined through anode plate casting and electrolysis in order to produce electrolytic nickel 99.98% pure. Deng, S. Y., & Gong, X. Z. (2018). Life Cycle Assessment of Nickel Production in China. Materials Science Forum, 913, 1004-1010. doi:10.4028/www.scientific.net/MSF.913.1004
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data are assumed to represent the average pyrometallurgical production of Nickel class 1 in China.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Majority of the data originated from national statistics [1], or process design data [2]. The calculation of the emissions was based on emissions factors on the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories. The inventory of electricity, coke, diesel and other basic energy come from Boxue Sun`s results [3]. The sources used for the provision of the dataset is listed below:
[1] China nonferrous metals industry association, The almanac of China nonferrous metals in-dustry, 2011-2015[M], The Almanac of China Nonferrous Metals Industry, 2011-2015.

[2] Heavy metal smelting design manual (copper nickel roll)[M], Metallurgical Industry Press, 2007.

[3] B.X. Sun, Z.R. Nie, Y. Liu, X.Z. Gong, F. Gao, Z.H. Wang, Research on life cycle CO2 emmissions of energy carriers in China[J], Materials Research Innovations, 18 (2014), 56-61.

exchanges.description: This waste has been included for completness purposes and it was not originally present in the data source. The amount of steam has been calculated through mass balance.

exchanges.description:
Elemental composition of coal (wt%): C: 84.4, H: 5.40, N: 1.70, S: 1.80 and O: 6.70. Source: Reid, William (1973). "Chapter 9: Heat Generation, Transport, and Storage". In Robert Perry; Cecil Chilton (eds.). Chemical Engineers' Handbook (5 ed.).The theoretical oxygen demand for combustion of hard coal was calculated based on the equation: 0.08*(C/3+H)+0.01*S-0.01*O . Source of Equation: 
Mazumdar, B. K. (2000). Theoretical oxygen requirement for coal combustion: relationship with its calorific value. Fuel, 79(11), 1413-1419. doi:<https://doi.org/10.1016/S0016-2361(99)00272-0>
